title: Fragment of a Temple Relief
description:
Fragment of limestone relief. In high relief, head of king wearing white crown, facing right. One incompletely preserved had outstretched towards incomplete object (? offerings). At upper edge two black cartouches. Presumably temple relief. 
Condition: Incomplete. Large chips at upper edge, on crown and on hand. No trace of paint.
section: The Late Period through the Beginning of the Roman Occupation

museum_location.name: 19th Dynasty to Roman Period, Martha A. and Robert S. Rubin Gallery, 3rd Floor

completeness.name: Best
completeness.description: All data has been vetted. Objects generally have quality photos and descriptions.

labels.content: The identity of the king depicted here is not known. His features resemble those of Nectanebo II, last king of Dynasty XXX (circa 380–342 B.C.), but he may be one of the Ptolemaic rulers. The empty cartouches do not necessarily imply that the scene was unfinished. The king\'s two names (the prenomen, or throne name, and the nomen, or family name) may have been painted and later lost. Alternatively, the cartouches may have been left blank to denote that the office of kingship itself mattered more than the particular king\'s identity.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art
